items.description: River Arrow and River Alne
items.message:
River levels are falling today but are forecast to rise again overnight or early tomorrow morning, Sunday 15 February 2026, as further rain/snow is forecast in next 24 hours.
Flooding remains possible on 14 and 15 February 2026. 
Flooding may affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks.

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 14 February 2026 and throughout this week. River levels at the Fosseway, Brokenborough, Great Somerford and Dauntsey gauges remain high but are currently stable or falling. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Saturday 14 February 2026 is expected to be mainly dry but further rainfall on Sunday 15 February 2026 may cause levels to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further alerts and warnings if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels today, 14 February 2026 may lead to flooding. This information is correct as of 15:30 on Saturday 14 February 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 41cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has up to 31cm of water on the road. No issues reported on the Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the Welney road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. items.message: High river levels are expected to continue to cause flooding on 14th February 2026. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow and river levels will remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Refer to local authority website for road closures. This message will be updated by 1pm on 15th February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The River Yeo level is 8.42m and is rising. The drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.50m and is stable. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are unable to pump due to high river levels but will start when conditions allow. Saturday (14/02/26) will be a fine dry day until further rainfall returns through the evening and overnight into Sunday. Monday will be a showery day and Tuesday is forecast to be another unsettled day. Catchments are saturated and rivers very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation and check flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 15/02/26, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High river levels on Sunday may lead to flooding.

River levels are currently falling. If the rainfall falls as forecast tomorrow (Sunday 15/02/2026), flooding is likely to affect land, fields, and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around, and affect, the mill building at East Wellow. Further rainfall is forecast on Tuesday (17/02/2026) and Wednesday (18/02/2026). We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have including pumps. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 16 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Overtopping is possible from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay. 
Saturday (14/2/26) will be a fine dry day until further rainfall returns through the evening and overnight into Sunday. Monday will be a showery day and Tuesday is forecast to be another unsettled day.
We continue to closely monitor the rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 15th February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.39m and is stable. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst above 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.545m and is falling. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is closed. For the latest levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Pumping at Currymoor has begun and will continue whilst river levels allow. Saturday (14/02/26) will be a fine dry day until further rainfall returns through the evening and overnight into Sunday. Monday will be a showery day and Tuesday is forecast to be another unsettled day. Catchments remain saturated and rivers are very responsive to rainfall. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and sluices. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 15/02/2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Monks Brook
items.message:
High river levels on Sunday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 15 February 2026 as rain is forecast (16mm). 
If rainfall falls as forecast tomorrow (Sunday 15/02/2026), flooding will affect the recreation ground at Fleming Park, and the river will be very high at Kingfisher Road. Surface water flooding in roads is also possible, affecting Chandlers Ford and at Stoneham Way from Chestnut Way to the M27. Further rainfall is forecast on Tuesday (17/02/2026) and Wednesday (18/02/2026). If the rain falls as forecast river levels and flood risk will remain high next week. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions . Report blockages to our hotline 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 16 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lymington River
items.message:
High river levels on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 13 February 2026 as rain is forecast (15mm). 
If rain falls as forecast this afternoon (Friday 13/02/2026), flooding will affect land and roads, including Burley Road, Brockenhurst. The river will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road, and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise from late afternoon today (13/02/2026) until tomorrow morning (Saturday 14/02/2026), but we do not expect impacts to property. Further rain is forecast on Sunday (15/02/2026). River levels and flood risk will remain high into next week. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Avoid driving through watersplash areas in Brockenhurst. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.39m and is stable. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst above 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.45m and is falling. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is closed. For the latest levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Pumping at Currymoor has begun and will continue whilst river levels allow. Saturday (14/02/26) will be a fine dry day until further rainfall returns through the evening and overnight into Sunday. Monday will be a showery day and Tuesday is forecast to be another unsettled day. Catchments remain saturated and rivers are very responsive to rainfall. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and sluices. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 15/02/2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message:
High river levels on Sunday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 15 February 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast (20mm). 
Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads, land at Riverside Caravan Centre, and the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road will continue on Saturday 14/02/2026. From the early hours of Sunday, widespread rain is predicted. From 08:00 on 15/02/2026, minor flood impacts could affect Barnham Road and Lake Lane, Barnham. The Barnham Rife should not rise as high as last Friday. The Aldingbourne Rife should rise less than twenty centimetres by Sunday evening. The Aldingbourne Rife should begin to fall in Bersted by Monday afternoon. Unsettled weather and flood risk could last until March. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris screens in Barnham. Our pumps at Felpham are running. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have including in Barnham. Avoid roads that flood (Barnham Road and Lake Lane). 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

If as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could affect fields, roads, and gardens along the River Lox and approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Flooding may also affect isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 04:00AM on 16/02/2026. An additional 20mm is possible on Tuesday night into Wednesday morning, which could cause flood risk to return.

This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Iwerne
items.message: High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. Flooding is expected from 9 February 2026 onwards. The groundwater level at the Iwerne Hill Farm borehole is at 115.44m, and is expected to remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, please take care when driving. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. Please do not drive through floodwater as this may cause bow waves. This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 16 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding.

Flooding is possible. 

Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley. We expect levels to rise over the next few weeks and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, on the 17 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message: High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. Groundwater levels in West Dorset are high and may rise further in response to recent rainfall. Areas that could be affected include: Charminster and nearby areas. The groundwater level at the Dickley Down borehole has risen to 168.37m.  Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 17 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Pimperne Brook
items.message: This is a Groundwater Flood Warning Update. Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Pimperne Brook at Pimperne. The groundwater level at Iwerne Hill Farm borehole is 116.22m, and is expected to remain high over the next few days. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should continue to keep any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers deployed. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the week which may see levels rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk. Please take care and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 18 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: A361 East Lyng to Burrowbridge
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.39m and is stable. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst above 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.45m and is falling. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is closed. For road closure information refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Pumping at Currymoor has begun and will continue whilst river levels allow. Saturday (14/02/26) will be a fine dry day until further rainfall returns through the evening and overnight into Sunday. Monday will be a showery day and Tuesday is forecast to be another unsettled day. Catchments remain saturated and rivers are responsive to rain. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking floodbanks, spillways and sluices. Please do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 15/02/2026, or as the situation changes

items.message: The level in the Westover Drain is falling slowly but levels remain high. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Parrett at Langport, with low lying land and roads most affected. Areas most at risk include Cheapside, Whatley Mews, Parrett Close, Bow Street, Moor Park and Westover Trading Estate. Saturday (14/02/26) will be a fine dry day until further rainfall returns through the evening and overnight into Sunday. items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible as a lot of rain (63mm) has fallen in the last week. 
Groundwater levels at the borehole at Pound Lane, Meonstoke are currently stable. Flooding is affecting the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane, Meonstoke. Water will be flowing across Rectory Lane, Meonstoke and behind the Buck's Head Pub. On Wednesday (11/02/2026), between 5 and 20mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. From Thursday (12/02/2026) to Saturday (14/02/2026), minimal rain is forecast. If only light rain affects the Meon Valley, groundwater levels will slowly fall. If heavier rain is recorded, the level will begin to rise once more and flooding at the Bucks Head pub may occur. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 17 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible as a lot of rain (66mm) has fallen in the last week. 
Widespread cellar flooding is now expected to be ongoing in Hambledon. Fareham Road is currently closed. Groundwater is infiltrating into sewers and causing issues with overflowing manholes. Further rain is expected from Friday (13/02/2026) to Monday (16/02/2026), with between 15 and 45mm of rain possible through these 4 days. The rate at which groundwater levels are rising has slowed. However, if heavy rain affects the area, it is possible that water levels may rise above the point at which road flooding has previously begun. The flood alleviation scheme is expected to minimise this impact. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 19 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Ems
items.message:
High river levels on Sunday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 15 February 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast (20mm). 
Minor flood impacts affecting fields, Brook Meadows, and rural roads will continue on Saturday 14/02/2026. Only scattered showers are forecast on Saturday, but river levels are not expected to fall much further than current levels. From the early hours of Sunday, widespread rain is predicted. From 08:00 on 15/02/2026, minor flooding could affect gardens of properties on North Street, River Street and at the Wren Centre, Westbourne. Also near Lumley Mill and Victoria Terrace, Emsworth. River levels should rise less than twenty centimetres. Unsettled weather could continue throughout February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , operating our structure at Constant Springs and clearing debris screens. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have including in Westbourne and Emsworth. Flooding may occur quickly. 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: The River Yeo level is 8.42m and rising slowly. The drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.50m and is stable. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are unable to pump due to high river levels but will start when conditions allow. Saturday (14/02/26) will be a fine dry day until further rainfall returns through the evening and overnight into Sunday. Monday will be a showery day and Tuesday is forecast to be another unsettled day. Catchments are saturated and rivers very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation and check flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 15/02/26 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message: Water levels in Saltmoor and Northmoor remain high today, Saturday 14th February. The drain level at Northmoor pumping station is 3.6m and at Northmoor Main Drain Remote is 4.47m and is falling. The level in Currymoor is falling but still very high. Athelney spillway continues to run into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Work has been undertaken to improve flow along Northmoor Main Drain to maximise pumping into the Parrett. Pumping at Currymoor has begun and will continue whilst river levels allow.  Saturday (14/02/26) will be a fine dry day until further rainfall returns through the evening and overnight into Sunday. Monday will be a showery day and Tuesday is forecast to be another unsettled day. Catchments are saturated and rivers very responsive to rainfall. We are monitoring the situation and checking floodbanks and spillways. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1pm on 15/02/26 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Denton
items.message: Groundwater is high, close to the surface, but now slowly falling at the Houndean Bottom borehole. Widespread rain is forecast Sunday morning. There is uncertainty in rainfall amounts. Between 10mm and 20mm. If the smaller amount of rain occurs, groundwater levels could continue to fall. If the maximum rain occurs, groundwater levels will likely rise again. Either way, groundwater flood impacts will continue all week. Probably until March. Springs will appear, water will affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. More rain is forecast Tuesday evening. If as much rain occurs as predicted, groundwater could rise until 22/02/2026, perhaps longer, and a small amount of water may appear on Denton Road, may flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. The weather outlook remains unsettled into March, although perhaps with rain less often. Take care on roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 18/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley

Between 10mm and 20mm. If the smaller amount of rain occurs, groundwater levels could continue to fall. If the maximum rain occurs, groundwater levels will likely rise again. Either way, groundwater flood impacts will continue all week. Probably until March. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, and water will flow down roads, including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden, between Cooks Lane and Barley Mow in Walderton, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane. Groundwater will also affect a small number of cellars in Stoughton and Walderton. More rain is forecast Tuesday evening. If as much rain occurs as predicted, groundwater could rise until 23/02/2026. Perhaps longer. The weather outlook remains unsettled into March, although perhaps with rain less often. Take care on roads that flood (Stoughton, Walderton). Ensure pumps work. We will update this message by 18:00 18/02/2026.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at Southampton Road Retail and Business Parks, Salisbury
items.message: This is a Flood Warning Update. Flooding is still possible. Flooding is expected at locations around the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Southampton Road Retail Park, Salisbury Business Park on Dairy Meadow Lane and Dairyhouse Bridge Caravan Site. River levels remain very high following the recent rainfall and the high groundwater. Further rain is forecast for the Sunday which may keep levels high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Activate any flood protection products you may have. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Check local authority websites for road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at The Friary and City Centre, Salisbury
items.message: This is an update to the current Flood Warning. River levels remain high due to recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding is expected, and locations most affected will be Fisherton Street, Bridge Street, Mill Road, Crane Street, New Street, Catherine Street, Brown Street, Exeter Street, Friary Lane, Greyfriars Close and Wiltshire College. More rainfall is expected Sunday which may cause further river level rise. We are closely monitoring the situation. Continue using any flood protection products you may have and acting on your flood plan if you have one. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Wallops
items.message:
High river levels on Sunday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 15 February 2026 as rain is forecast (16mm). 
River levels remain high and are currently stable. Flooding is continuing to affect low lying land and Horsebridge Road, Broughton, and will be close to property at Duck’s Lane, Church Street and The Square at Nether Wallop, where it may flood gardens. If the rainfall falls as forecast tomorrow (Sunday 15/02/2026), river levels will rise. Further rainfall is forecast on Tuesday (17/02/2026) and Wednesday (18/02/2026). River levels and flood risk will remain high for the next few weeks. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 16 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible , as a lot of rain (56mm) has fallen in the last week. 
The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are now flowing. Flooding is expected in Finchdean, including the flooding of Chalton Road. Road flooding will be deep in all villages. Cellar flooding is expected in Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle. Pumps which may prevent water from entering property will be required. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. Small amounts of rain are forecast from today (09/02/2026) until Thursday (12/02/2026). Groundwater levels at the borehole in Finchdean are expected to continue rising throughout this week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 16 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lower Allen Vale
items.message: Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Lower Allen Vale including New Town, Witchampton. The groundwater level at Woodyates borehole is 106.09m,  there is further rainfall expected this week which will keep levels high over the next few days. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 18 February 2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible as a lot of rain (50mm) has fallen in the last week. 
Flooding is affecting cellars in a small number of properties along Winchester Road, central King's Somborne and in Little Somborne. Water in the ford off Winchester Road is now very high. From today (Wednesday 11/02/2026) to Sunday (15/02/2026), further rain (between 20 and 50mm) is forecast to affect Hampshire. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising over the next week. If the heavier rain in the forecast affects the area, then from next week, impacts to the sewerage system may occur and water in the stream could come out of bank at Old Vicarage Lane. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 18 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. 
Further rainfall is forecast but no further flooding is expected. The river is draining again at low tide as we move out of the neap cycle. The risk from tide locking has subsided. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: River Lavant
items.message:
High river levels on Sunday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 15 February 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast (20mm). 
Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads and gardens will continue on Saturday. In East Lavant, water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane, the Green, and bridges across the river. From 02:00 on Sunday, widespread rain is forecast. If as much rain falls as predicted, from 10:00 on 15/02/2026, river levels could rise a small amount. In addition to existing impacts, minor flooding could also affect gardens of properties at The Sadlers in Westhampnett. River levels should rise less than ten centimetres. River levels should begin to fall by Monday. River levels could remain high until March. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and operating structures at Westhampnett for the Flood Alleviation Scheme. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood, Sheepwash Lane. Report blockages to 0800 80 70 60 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Littleton, Headbourne, Kings and Martyr Worthy, Easton and Chilland
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible , as a lot of rain (49mm) has fallen in the last week. 
Flooding is affecting Springvale Road in Kings Worthy. In Martyr Worthy, Chilland and Easton drainage ditches and culverts will become full and less effective as natural flow paths are restricted. Some properties may be affected as water seeps up through floors. Footpaths near the river will also become inaccessible. In Littleton, cellar flooding and road flooding could occur from Thursday (12/02/2026). Small amounts of rain are forecast from today (09/02/2026) until Thursday (12/02/2026). Groundwater levels could continue to rise slowly until the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 16 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Areas of Chertsey closest to the Chertsey Bourne
items.message:
High river levels may cause flooding today, 14 February 2026.

Flooding is possible on 14 February 2026.

Flooding of property and roads remains possible today in the Chertsey area, especially at Eastworth Road and Hamm Court. Heavy rain is forecast for tomorrow morning. River levels have dropped below the flood risk threshold but are forecast to rise back through the threshold in response to tomorrow's rain.

We are closely monitoring the situation. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.

Stay away from flood water - it contains hidden dangers such as open man hole covers, sewage and chemicals. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10am on 15 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Haslemere and Churt areas
items.message:
Rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding.

Flooding is possible from 10 February 2026. 

Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Frith Cottage borehole near the Haslemere and Churt areas. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few days. We expect groundwater levels to continue slowly rising over the next few weeks due to sustained rainfall across the area. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. 

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 17 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Patcham
items.message: Groundwater is high, very close to the surface, but now slowly falling. In Patcham village, groundwater will probably continue to steadily rise all week. Widespread rain is forecast Sunday morning. There is uncertainty in rainfall amounts. Between 10mm and 20mm. If the smaller amount of rain occurs, groundwater levels at Ladies Mile could continue to fall. If the maximum rain occurs, groundwater levels at Ladies Mile will likely rise again. Either way, groundwater flood impacts will continue all week. Probably until March. A small amount of water could appear in a few basements. Previous events suggest impacts may initially affect Old London Road, Patcham and Peacock Lane, Withdean. More rain is forecast Tuesday evening. If as much rain occurs as predicted, groundwater could rise until 23/02/2026, perhaps longer, and a small amount of water may appear on roads. The weather outlook remains unsettled into March, although perhaps with rain less often. Ensure pumps work. We are liaising with Brighton and Hove City Council. We will update this message by 18:00 18/02/2026.

items.description: Winchester Itchen
items.message:
High river levels on Friday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 13 February 2026 as rain is forecast (15mm). 
Flooding is continuing to affect North Walls Recreation Ground and River Park. Winchester City Council have installed a number of flood barriers around Park Avenue, River Park, and Water Lane. If rain falls as forecast this afternoon (Friday 13/02/2026), river levels will rise. Further rainfall is forecast on Sunday (15/02/2026). River levels will remain high for the next few weeks. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Flood water could be deep. Winnall Moors Nature Reserve may be closed. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 15 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Bourne at Southampton Road Industrial Park, Salisbury
items.message:
This is a Flood Warning Update. River levels remain high and flooding is still possible. Areas most at risk include Southampton Road Retail Park, Salisbury Business Park on Dairy Meadow Lane and Dairyhouse Bridge Caravan Site. 
River levels remain very high following recent rainfall and the high groundwater.  The weather remains unsettled and further rain is forecast over the weekend.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Activate any flood protection products you may have. 
Please take care and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 16 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the upper Avon valley and the Nine Mile river
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected in response to recent rainfall. 
Areas that could be affected include: Upper Avon Valley and the Nine Mile River. The groundwater level at Everleigh borehole has risen to 135.10m, and is expected to continue to rise into next week in response to recent rainfall. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 17 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Alton area
items.message:
Rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 10th February 2026. 
Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Farringdon borehole near Alton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year. We expect levels to rise over the next few weeks due to sustained rainfall across the area. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 17 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Coln from Fossebridge to Quennington
items.message:
High river levels on the River Coln may cause flooding. 

River levels are slowly falling on the River Coln. Flooding of property and roads is still expected though, especially nearest the River Coln in the Fossebridge and Bibury areas. Further rain is forecast overnight and tomorrow, which has the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue slowly falling overnight, but levels will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Activate any flood protection products you may have. Go to River Levels Online for updates on current river levels. Stay away from flood water - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.  

This message will be updated by 11:00AM on the 15 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible to low lying land, roads and properties with basements around these areas, 
Petham Bourne, Alkham bourne and Nailbourne including Alkham, Elham, Barham, Bishopsbourne, Bridge, Patrixbourne and Bekesbourne. Groundwater levels in East Kent have been rising following significantly wetter conditions since January. Levels are continuing to increase in February in response to heavy rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk . Riparian owners are reminded to keep rivers on their land clear. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 20 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
